Description: Egyptian terracotta female figure, seated. Cloak is pulled back revealing chest. Left side and face only. Mould-made and hollow with white coating. Dark red-brown Nile silt fabric with grey core. Abundant fine gold mica, quartz and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Gutch dates this to 150BC-250AD (Gutch in Hogarth 1899; pl. 12. no. 172). From same mould as NA533 also now in Cambridge. The squinting eye style is often attributed to Roman and possibly later Hellenistic figures, though this may not be a chronological feature as there is a 2nd to 1st century BC parallel from Egypt (Török 1995; pl. 122. no. 227) and also late 3rd century BC example in Dresden (Fischer 1994, no. 54). Fischer, J. 1994. Griechisch- römische Terrakotten aus Ägypten. Die Sammlungen Sieglin und Schreiber. Dresden, Leipzig, Stuttgart, Tübingen. Tübingen, Wasmuth. Török, L. 1995. Hellenistic and Roman terracottas from Egypt. Roma.
Bibliographic references: Gutch 1898/1899 / Excavations at Naukratis, D. The Terracottas (p. 91-2, no. 172, pl. XII, no.172)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.464) (Phase 1)
